Expectation1: Respond to emails and messages within a reasonable time frame
Situation1: The message is informational and the sender notes there is no immediate action required.
Situation2: They notice swimmers occasionally entering the shallow area without supervision.
Story: I sat in the lifeguard chair, the sun beating down on my shoulders, my phone buzzing in my pocket. I glanced at the pool, scanning for any signs of trouble. Out of the corner of my eye, I saw a group of kids edging into the shallow end, giggling and splashing, no adult in sight. My training kicked in—no unsupervised swimmers, especially kids. I was about to blow my whistle when my phone buzzed again. It was a message from a colleague, just an update about a project. “No immediate action required,” she’d written, but I knew the unspoken rule: respond quickly, show you’re engaged, be a team player. I felt the pressure mounting—if I didn’t reply soon, would I seem uncommitted? But if I looked away from the pool, even for a moment, what if something happened? My mind raced, torn between the silent expectations of my office and the urgent responsibility of the water. I gripped my phone, heart pounding, caught between two worlds, unsure which demand to answer first.
